security_audit.summary: Official skill content contains only documentation and an Apache 2.0 license; no executable code, network access, or filesystem interactions present.

content.user_title: Apply Anthropic brand colors & typography to artifacts
content.value_statement: Inconsistent visuals across decks and documents make outputs feel unprofessional and off-brand. This skill provides Anthropic’s official color palette and typography rules so you can style artifacts consistently and quickly.
actual_capabilities: Provides Anthropic-approved hex color palette (main + accent colors)
Defines typography guidance: Poppins for headings and Lora for body with fallbacks
Specifies simple rules for smart font application (headings 24pt+ vs body text)
Describes on-brand accent usage for non-text shapes (cycling orange/blue/green)
Notes implementation intent for RGB-precise color application (e.g., python-pptx RGBColor)
limitations: No executable formatter included here; it supplies guidelines rather than a runnable styling tool
Font results depend on whether Poppins and Lora are installed; otherwise fallbacks apply
Does not include layout, spacing, grid, iconography, or logo usage rules
Color application details are conceptual and may require adaptation for your target platform/tool

use_cases.title: Make a pitch deck look on-brand
use_cases.description: Apply the official Anthropic palette and font hierarchy to slides so headings, body text, and accents feel consistent and polished.

use_cases.title: Brand a generated report
use_cases.description: Style auto-generated charts, tables, and headings with the approved colors and typography to match company design standards.

use_cases.title: Standardize visuals across teams
use_cases.description: Share a single, documented source of truth for colors and typography rules to reduce drift across documents and presentations.

prompt_templates.title: Beginner: Restyle a document
prompt_templates.prompt: Apply Anthropic brand styling to this content. Use the official main colors and accent colors, and set headings to Poppins (fallback Arial) and body to Lora (fallback Georgia). Return styled guidance I can follow in [PowerPoint/Google Slides/Docs].

prompt_templates.title: Intermediate: Slide-by-slide styling checklist
prompt_templates.prompt: Given this 10-slide outline, produce a slide-by-slide styling plan using Anthropic brand colors and typography. Specify background color, heading/body colors, and which accent color to use for shapes per slide.

prompt_templates.title: Advanced: Programmatic styling spec
prompt_templates.prompt: Generate a programmatic styling specification for applying Anthropic brand styling to a PPTX via python-pptx: RGB values for each color, rules for heading detection (24pt+), body styling, and accent cycling for shapes.

prompt_templates.title: Expert: Accessibility and contrast pass
prompt_templates.prompt: Review my draft styling choices against Anthropic brand colors and typography. Adjust colors to maintain strong contrast on light/dark backgrounds and propose an accessible, consistent scheme while staying on-brand.

best_practices: Use Dark (#141413) on Light (#faf9f5) for primary readability, and invert for dark themes
Reserve accent colors for emphasis and shapes; keep most text in main colors for consistency
Pre-install Poppins and Lora in your environment to avoid typography drift across machines
anti_patterns: Using accents (orange/blue/green) for large paragraphs of body text
Mixing in extra non-brand colors that dilute the palette
Assuming fonts will render identically without verifying font availability and fallbacks

faq.question: What platforms does this work with?
faq.answer: It provides brand colors and typography rules that can be applied in any tool (e.g., PowerPoint, Google Slides, Figma, Docs). The repository content itself is documentation, not a tool-specific plugin.

faq.question: Are there any usage limits?
faq.answer: No runtime limits are defined because there is no executable service here—only the documented palette and styling rules.

faq.question: Can I integrate this into an automated pipeline?
faq.answer: Yes, by translating the documented palette and font rules into your pipeline (for example, a python-pptx script using RGB values). This repo describes intended application patterns but does not ship the pipeline code.

faq.question: Is my data sent anywhere?
faq.answer: No. The provided files are an Apache 2.0 license and a markdown guideline document; there is no code that reads files, accesses environment variables, or makes network requests.

faq.question: Why don’t my fonts match the guideline exactly?
faq.answer: Poppins and Lora must be installed in the environment for best results. If unavailable, the guidance specifies fallbacks (Arial for headings, Georgia for body).

faq.question: How does this compare to a full design system?
faq.answer: This is a focused subset: colors and typography application guidance. A full design system typically also includes spacing, components, logo rules, imagery, iconography, and accessibility standards.
